awd_titl_txt: Developmental and interpersonal antecedents of parenting orientations and behavior: A life history perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
Few events in life rival the importance of raising children. Compared to most species, humans invest heavily in their children, but some parents are neglectful, indifferent, or even hostile toward their children. This project examines why certain parents tend to invest more versus less time, effort, attention, support, and resources in their children. Little is currently known about: (a) what kinds of early-life events/experiences lead individuals to become more versus less investing parents in adulthood and (b) how parental investment is affected by the quality of the  relationship with one's partner. In addition, the role that fathers play in parenting has been under studied, and relatively little is known about how partners co-parent their children as a function of their early-life experiences or the quality of their relationship. This research addresses these issues and is aimed at filling these critical gaps in knowledge and understanding of parenting practices and behavior.

Two studies will address these aims. In Study 1, new codings and analyses will be conducted on a unique longitudinal sample that has lifespan data on parenting outcomes (the Minnesota Longitudinal Study of Risk and Adaptation; MLSRA). Participants in this sample have been continuously followed from before birth into middle adulthood. The MLSRA has excellent measures of how individuals were treated as children, what happened to them across development, and how they are parenting their own children years later in adulthood. This study will examine how certain early life experiences (e.g., the amount of life stress, the occurrence of maltreatment) prospectively predict parents' views about investing time, effort, and resources in their children and how they actually behave (based on video-recordings) when interacting with their children. Study 2 is a new laboratory study of parenting behavior involving mothers, fathers, and their first-born toddlers. This study, which involves video-recording mothers, fathers, and their toddler engaging in parenting tasks, will: (a) examine whether certain types of perceived early-life stress are associated with parenting attitudes and behavior in a family context, (b) investigate whether the quality of the partners' relationship buffers exposure to early-life stress, (c) identify whether certain types of perceived early-life stress are associated with fathers' and mothers' implicit (vs. explicit) parenting attitudes, and (d) determine whether implicit parenting attitudes mediate the relation between early-life stress and parenting attitudes and behavior.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Aims and Goals: Most parents invest heavily in their children, but some are neglectful, indifferent, or even hostile. Relatively ittle is known about the early-life predictors of positive vs. negative parenting practices and how they are associated with the quality of parents' romantic relationship in shaping parenting outcomes. The current research fills critical gaps in our knowledge of how BOTH early and current interpersonal experiences are related to parenting attitudes and behavior by: (1) analyzing a longitudinal dataset that has lifespan data on parenting outcomes (the Minnesota Longitudinal Study of Risk and Adaptation; MLSRA), and (2) conducting a triadic behavioral observation lab study of parenting involving mothers, fathers, and their first-born toddlers.

The goals of the MLSRA study (Aim 1) were to: (a) investigate whether certain early-life variables (e.g., being maltreated as a child) prospectively predict parenting outcomes in adulthood, (b) test whether certain variables (e.g., social competence with peers in childhood) mediate this association, and (c) determine whether features of parents' current romantic relationship (e.g., being in a committed, satisfying relationship, receiving more support from one's partner) prevent parents who were exposed to early-life stress from becoming less investing parents.

The goals of the triadic lab study (Aim 2) were to: (a) examine whether certain types or amounts of perceived early-life stress are associated with parenting orientations and behavior, (b) investigate whether certain features of the current romantic relationship buffer (protect against) exposure to early-life stress, (c) identify whether different types or amounts of perceived early-life stress are associated with fathers' and/or mothers' implicit (vs. explicit) parenting attitudes, and (d) determine whether implicit parenting attitudes mediate the link between early-life stress and explicit parenting attitudes.

Current Findings: The COVID pandemic delayed the data collection of the triadic lab study, which was not completed until June 2022.  Thus, we are still coding the videorecorded behavioral interactions between parents and their toddlers.  The primary results of the MLSRA longitudinal study, however, have been completed.

Approximately 110 MLSRA participants, all of whom have been studied since they were born in 1975-76, have had at least one child. Thus, we had access to the following measures for each MLSRA participant: Early maltreatment severity (ages 0-5 years) was assessed using the sum of experiences of abuse and/or neglect during infancy and early childhood. Socio-emotional competence during middle childhood and adolescence (ages 5-16 years) was assessed with a composite of teacher ratings of the child's (MLSRA participant's) social competence and emotional health in kindergarten, 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 6th grades, and in high school. Adult parenting was assessed using a semi-structured interview administered to all MLSRA participants who were parents at age 32. The coded interview scales of positive emotional connectedness, investment/involvement, and low hostility were averaged to create a positive parental orientation score. We also used an observational measure of parental supportive presence, which relied on coded interactions of MLSRA participants (who were of various ages at the time) with their 24- and 42-months old children. The size of participants' social networks at age 32 was indexed by the number of individuals they indicated were part of their inner, middle, or outer social circles.

As predicted, MLSRA participants who experienced maltreatment earlier in life displayed less socio-emotional competence during childhood, which in turn predicted less positive parental orientations and poorer observed parental supportive presence when they were parents. Also as predicted, having a larger social network buffered (protected against) the negative effects of early maltreatment, with the total number of friends in a participant's social network strengthening this protective effect.

These findings indicate that childhood maltreatment is indeed a risk factor for impaired socio-emotional development, which then forecasts less positive and less supportive parenting later in life. However, having a larger social network of close friends appears to act as a protective factor against the negative effects of early maltreatment on later parenting in adulthood.

Intellectual Merit: This research fills two noteworthy gaps in our knowledge. First, unlike prior parenting studies, most of which have assessed retrospective reports of childhood experiences, our research tests models using a prospective, longitudinal design with individuals assessed since birth. Second, we conducted a lab study in which families (the mother, father, and oldest toddler) were videotaped while interacting in different structured situations designed to assess the type and amount of supportive care provided by both parents, including parents' degree of coordination, cooperation, and mutual support while co-parenting their toddler. 

Broader Impacts: The proposed research should have two broader impacts. First, the questions that this research addresses are highly interdisciplinary, drawing from theoretical and empirical literatures in evolutionary biology, family relations, social/personality psychology, and child development. Second, this research will help us determine when and how during the life-course interventions designed to improve the quality of parenting should be administered.
